incident_updates.body: Users experienced that Pipelines page in the UI was unresponsive from 21:29 - 21:39 UTC on January 25, 2023. We have since rolled back the change that caused this issue. The Pipelines page is now working as expected.

As of Friday, January 13th, 2023, we have updated our blog post with the Incident Report regarding the January 4th Security Incident. Please review the update for the most accurate information and recommendations to our customers.

https://circleci.com/blog/jan-4-2023-incident-report/

As of Thursday, January 12th, 2023 at 00:30 UTC, we have updated our blog post with additional information regarding the January 4th Security Incident. Please review the update for the most accurate information and recommendations to our customers.

https://circleci.com/blog/january-4-2023-security-alert/

On January 4, 2023, we alerted customers of a security incident and recommended customers rotate all secrets and environment variables stored in CircleCI. Please refer to the following blog post for the most up-to-date recommendations to our customers. We are committed to publishing an incident report on January 17, 2023 (PST). 

https://circleci.com/blog/january-4-2023-security-alert/

incidents.name: GitLab pipelines are not triggering for some users

incident_updates.body:
This incident has now been resolved. Pipelines on new Gitlab projects will run successfully again.

We would like to thank you once again for your patience.

We have determined that the issue was due to a third party provider and have implemented a temporary workaround while this is being resolved. Any customers who are experiencing this issue should remove and re-add their project. Pipelines on newly set up projects should run now. Thank you for your patience!
We are still working on the fix but we will post an update within an hour or as soon as we have more information to share. Thank you for bearing with us while we are working on this.
We are continuing to work on a fix for the issues we are experiencing and will update once again in one hour or as soon we have more information to share.
We continue working on the fix for the issue affecting pipeline on newly set up Gitlab projects. We will provide update within 1 hour or when we have more news to share.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
We continue working on a fix. The issue only affects pipelines on newly configured GitLab projects.
We are continuing to work on a fix for the issue preventing pipelines from running in newly set up GitLab projects.
We have identified the source of the issue blocking some GitLab pipelines from running, and a fix is being implemented.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating an issue where new triggers set for GitLab projects are not triggering pipelines.

incidents.name: Some GitLab Pipelines Are Not Running For Some Users

incident_updates.body:
We are working on a permanent solution to this issue. Until then, the workaround to recreate the Configuration Sources can be used.
Please contact support if you encounter further issues.

We would like to thank you again for your patience

While we continue to work on a permanent solution to this issue, we still recommend that you work around this behavior by going to your “Project Settings” -> “Configuration” in the CircleCI UI, then deleting and recreating the configuration source as well as any triggers associated with the problematic config.

We are continuing to see some GitLab pipelines failing to fetch config files. If you see this issue we recommend that you work around it by going to your “Project Settings” -> “Configuration” in the CircleCI UI, then deleting and recreating the configuration source as well as any triggers associated with the problematic config.

We would like to thank you for your patience while we work on a permanent fix.
If you are seeing a message "Error fetching config" in the UI you can work around this issue by going to "Project Settings" -> "Configuration" and deleting and recreating the configuration source.
We are currently investigating reports that some GitLab pipelines are not running for some of our users

## Incident Report: Sept 22, 2022 - Major - All Orbs Inaccessible

## Summary:

On September 21, 2022, at 22:29 UTC, the orb index was inadvertently deleted due to an incorrect command being issued in a production database. This resulted in all orbs being unavailable, and jobs referencing orbs to fail, for the duration of the incident. We were able to restore the majority of the contents of that database, however the most recent backup at that time was 45 minutes old and any changes to orbs during that 45 minute window were lost. We want to apologize for any disruption this might have caused and to thank our customers for their patience and understanding as we worked to restore normal service.

## What Happened

\(all times UTC\)

On September 21, 2022, for 76 minutes beginning at 22:29, any job that referenced an any orb would fail with an error stating that the referenced orb couldn’t be found. Additionally, orb pages in the registry would return a `404 Not Found` error, and orbs in the CircleCI UI and CLI were inaccessible. Jobs that did not utilize orbs were unaffected.

This issue was traced back to an incorrectly entered command being issued against all orbs in their database. In most circumstances, our teams utilize our internal administrative tools to remove orbs per a customer request. In this instance, however, an error in that tooling required an engineer to perform a manual operation to remove the requested orb. During that process, an incorrectly entered command caused the removal of all orbs from the database rather than the specific orb requested.

An incident was declared at 22:48, moving to identified at 22:50. Once identified, the team set about restoring the orbs database to a known good state. On first pass, the team restored a database snapshot from earlier that same day. At this point, 58 minutes after the incident began, functionality was restored and jobs referencing orbs began completing as expected.

Following that, at 23:45, the team began retrieving orb changes that occurred between the snapshot time and the time of the deletion. They were able to restore all but the then most recent 45 minutes of changes and the incident was resolved at 00:16.

With that, any potential changes made to orbs on September 21, 2022 between 21:44 and 22:29 would have been lost. No other customer data, aside from orbs, was affected.

## Future Prevention and Process Improvement:

Ultimately, human errors are system problems that we can and will solve. In this case, an error in our internal tooling led to a manual procedure that lacked sufficient guardrails to prevent a mistake from occurring. Going forward, we have removed this specific process for deleting orbs through direct access to our production database and we are improving our internal administrative tooling to appropriately handle orb removal with abundant safeguards in place.

Additionally, the time required to restore data from our backups was longer than we consider acceptable. We’re actively working to improve our backup and restore procedures and documentation to ensure that any downtime required to restore missing data in the future is minimized.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our September 21st incident: https://stspg.io/3zbsfr16g7d8

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. If you encounter issues with any specific orb versions please contact support. We appreciate your patience and understanding.

A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results. Jobs utilizing orbs should begin to run as usual again. We have restored the data up until 10 hours ago. This mean that ~5 orbs have updates that haven't been restored yet. We are starting on restoring the data for those orbs now.
As we continue working on a solution, please avoid publishing orbs. This will be a temporary ask for the duration of this incident.
We are continuing our work on deploying a fix. Customers utilizing orbs are still experiencing job failures. We deeply apologize for this inconvenience and thank you for your patience.
The cause for this issue has been identified. Thank you for your patience as we are working on a solution.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
Users are seeing jobs fail when utilizing orbs. We are investigating the cause for this disruption at this time.

## Incident Report: 2022-09-14 - Pipelines not loading

## Summary:

On September 14, 2022 from approximately 07:45 to 17:05 UTC, customer pipelines were delayed due to an issue with high load on an internal database that is central to coordinating and orchestrating work on our platform. During this window, all customer pipelines experienced delays in starting. As part of the remediation effort, parts of the the application UI were disabled to reduce load on the impacted system between 08:21 and 15:34 UTC.

The original status page can be found here: [Pipelines not loading](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/2ccnm7m0gpgs) 

We want to thank our customers for your patience and understanding as we worked to resolve this incident.

## What Happened

At approximately 07:40 UTC on September 14, there was a sudden increase in disk I/O and CPU utilization on two read-only replicas of a database that is part of the system responsible for coordinating and orchestrating work on the CircleCI platform. By 07:54 internal circuit breakers tripped and an incident was declared.

During the incident, engineers rolled the pods of the affected services several times in an attempt to terminate slow-running queries and free up connection pools. The team also enabled an “incident mode” flag that disables portions of the application user interface to help reduce the volume of calls into the database.

This did succeed in reducing the load temporarily, but the load would quickly spike again as the work queue backed up. After further analysis, the team determined that there were a number of factors contributing to the database load:

* There was a standard background process running that was intended to help clean stale data.
* A recent change to a database library had enabled SQL comments, and there was a hypothesis that this change had impacted the database’s internal statistics engine due to increasing cardinality of query strings, leading to additional load.
* A database internal maintenance process started right as the load increased, apparently tipping the system over the edge.
* Finally, the replicas had originally been sized smaller than the primary, but as additional workloads have shifted to the replicas they were not able to support the same load as the primary. This also contributed to replication lag from the primary, consuming resources and further slowing the responsiveness of the affected system.

All of these factors contributed to pushing the affected database into a state where it could not keep up with the workload.

The system was restored to full functionality by scaling up the replicas to match the primary and reverting the change to the database library.

By 17:05 UTC, the remediation work was completed, all pipelines were processing normally and the UI was re-enabled. Customer builds did continue to flow \(at reduced capacity\) for the entire duration of the incident, however in retrospect we did not communicate this effectively during the incident.

## Future Prevention and Process Improvement:

Our database engineers have initiated a review and audit of our critical systems to evaluate and shift applicable workloads \(like reporting and analytics\) away from critical production systems. This work has been completed for the workflow system affected by this incident, and is ongoing and is targeted for completion by the end of 2022 for the remainder of our critical systems.

The change to enable SQL comments has now been gated behind a configuration flag and is not enabled by default.

We are working to revise our incident process to help facilitate more effective communication to our customers during incidents.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our September 14th incident: https://stspg.io/bpbdxyx2nk6f

incidents.name: Delays in processing incoming webhooks from Bitbucket

incident_updates.body:
We observed that between September 5, 9:22 [UTC] and September 6, 8:48 [UTC], one of our services had returned `500` errors to incoming webhooks from Bitbucket.

This behaviour occurred for a very small subset of incoming webhooks from Bitbucket.

As a result, a few users may have experienced an issue where pipelines would start with a delay after pushing commits to the related Bitbucket repository(-ies).

We have since reverted changes that we believe are involved in this unexpected/unwanted behaviour, and we are currently further investigating to identify the exact cause.

Please accept our apologies for the disruption. If you have any question regarding this issue, feel free to contact CircleCI Support.
Remote connectivity issues on checkout considered transient at this time, with shallow checkout and retries advised as a temporary workaround for customers seeing this issue.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.

incident_updates.body: A recent deployment affected may have had an affect on CircleCI API v2 with 500 Errors. Customers may have seen that the UI for cross-project pipelines were down. Downtime was about 10 minutes, but no builds or workflows were affected.

On July 19, 2022, from 20:02 to 21:47 UTC, customers experienced delays of up to 10 minutes in job start time. We want to thank our customers for your patience and understanding as we worked to resolve this incident.  
  
The original status page can be found [here](https://status.circleci.com/incidents/khp3zkvprtp3).  
  
**What happened** \(all times UTC\)

At approximately 18:55, one of our database clusters began to show elevated read activity, with a corresponding increase in disk I/O and CPU utilization.  
  
This activity increased over time, and by 19:30, this began to impact customer job start time through increased request latency. 

On-call engineers were alerted, and a public incident was declared at 20:02. At 20:12, the database connection pools became saturated and new connections began to fail, contributing to delays in job start times as our system was slow to process workloads during the event. 

Through investigation the team discovered an unusually high amount of requests generated from a specific API endpoint. Steps were taken to address the additional load, and at 21:15 we restarted services with “hung” database connections. This freed up the connection pool and allowed the team to scale up services responsible for processing job output to work through the backlog. This succeeded in reducing the database pressure and processing returned to normal by 21:25.

During this incident, most customers experienced increased job start times of up to 10 minutes and delays in both status updates and the availability of job output. A smaller number of customers experienced “stuck” jobs that presented as jobs showing as “queued” or “started” with no progress. These had to be manually stopped and restarted.  
  
**Future Prevention and Process Improvement:**

We are prioritizing work to decouple job execution from this database. Once this is complete, a similar incident may result in a delay in displaying job output but should not impact job start or overall execution and job status results.

Our teams are also analyzing and improving rate limiting logic for specific inter-service APIs in order to prevent excessive request load.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our July 20th incident: https://stspg.io/g8w8czk3s4f0

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. Thank you for your patience.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring results. Jobs are beginning to run again as normal.
We have identified the root of this issue. We are implementing a fix.
We are still seeing job latency of around 5 minutes. We are diligently working to identify this issue.
We are continuing to see latency in job starts, averaging around 7 minutes. We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are seeing delays of up to 10 minutes on job start time. We are currently investigating the source of this issue.

incidents.name: Config Processing is Experiencing Unexpected Slowness

incident_updates.body: This incident has now been resolved by our team.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
Our config processing is experiencing unexpected slowness causing some builds to fail. We are currently looking into the cause of this issue

incidents.name: [MINOR] Unauthorized users are not able to view Open-Source Projects in the UI

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved. If any affected users continue to experience difficulties in the UI, please contact CircleCI support.
A fix to roll back has been implemented and we are now monitoring.
We are currently investigating this issue - Builds are not affected. This only affects Open Source Unauthenticated projects.

incidents.name: Slow page load times for the pipelines page

incident_updates.body: This incident has now been resolved by our team.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently working on a fix to resolve the issue
We are aware of an issue which is causing slow page load times for the pipelines page and our team is currently investigating this issue.

During the period from 16:36 to 19:30 UTC, customers experienced errors creating new GitLab projects, configs, and triggers. This issue has been resolved. Please contact support if you continue to see issues.

incidents.name: Failure to startup Job using Windows Server 2022 image

incident_updates.body: We are now observing normal operation. Thank you for your patience throughout this incident.
We have implemented a fix and are currently monitoring the result. Customers can re-run previously failed workflows.
We continue to see a number of jobs failing to start using Windows Server 2022 images. We are continuing to investigate the cause of the incident. Thanks for your patience while we investigate.
We are investigating where job using Windows Server 2022 image does not start successfully.

incident_updates.body: The incident is now resolved.
We experienced delays for all jobs between 12:03 and 12:12 UTC. We have mitigated the impact and are now seeing regular behaviour. We are continuing to monitor the impact.

incidents.name: MacOS Fleet is Experiencing Longer Git Checkout Times

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented by the upstream provider to the ISP and we are continuing to monitor.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

The ISP used by the macOS fleet is experiencing an incident resulting in packet loss. This has led to longer git checkout times. The ISP is working on a fix and we will provide updates as soon as they become available. Thank you for your patience.

components.name: macOS Jobs
components.description: CircleCI jobs using the macos executor.

incidents.name: Some macOS jobs failed to run

incident_updates.body: An issue with our macOS provisioner prevented a limited number of macOS jobs from running for a period between 10:00 UTC and 10:48 UTC. The issue is now resolved and any affected jobs can be re-run.

A recent change made the Trigger Page unaccessible with 403 errors. 

This change has since been reverted, bringing back original functionality. The Trigger page and any functionality related should be accessible.

We identified an issue in our pipelines scheduler that prevented scheduled pipelines from running between Jun 21 17:27 UTC and Jun 22 10:51 UTC. We have implemented a fix and future scheduled pipelines will now run as normal. 

Please submit a commit to your branch or trigger a pipeline in the UI or via the API if you require any missed pipelines to run.
This incident is now resolved. You should see builds starting up as normal again. Thank you again for your patience.
We are monitoring the situation as builds are beginning to run as normal again. We are seeing VM assignment recovering.

One of our networking providers is experiencing intermittent issues with network connectivity, which is causing some jobs to fail.
We expect the network issues to resolve soon, but in the meantime retrying jobs may be successful. Thank you for your patience.
The issue has been identified and we are working on a solution.
Currently, macOS jobs are seeing long spin up and queue times.
We are continuing to investigate this issue. All macOS resource classes seem to be affected at this time.
We are experiencing a high number of failed macOS jobs. We are investigating the root cause of this issue.

incident_updates.body: We are continuing to see usual performance. Thank you for your patience while we investigated this issue.
We are now seeing jobs running as normal. We will continue to monitor performance.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are starting to see jobs running again. Some Docker jobs may be delayed. We are continuing to investigate the cause.
We are currently experiencing an issue preventing jobs from running. We are currently investigating the cause.
